summary: This is a grand jury subpoena issued by the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, commanding an unnamed recipient to appear before the grand jury on August 20, 2019, and to produce all materials relating to Jeffrey Epstein. The subpoena is signed by U.S. Attorney Geoffrey S. Berman and includes a rider detailing the recipient's rights and the scope of the document request.

persons.name: Geoffrey S. Berman
persons.role: United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: He is the signatory of the grand jury subpoena, commanding the recipient to appear and produce documents related to Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subpoena demands the production of all materials relating to him, indicating he is the central subject of the grand jury investigation.

connections.description: Berman, as U.S. Attorney, is issuing a subpoena to gather evidence for a grand jury investigation into Epstein.

events.title: Grand Jury Appearance
events.description: The unnamed recipient is commanded to appear before the Grand Jury for the Southern District of New York to testify and give evidence.

events.title: Subpoena Issued
events.description: The grand jury subpoena is dated and issued by U.S. Attorney Geoffrey S. Berman.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, Room 220, Borough of Manhattan, City of New York, New York
One St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: A grand jury subpoena was issued on August 15, 2019, for an appearance on August 20, 2019, indicating active federal investigation into Jeffrey Epstein after his 2019 arrest.
The subpoena demands the production of 'All materials relating to Jeffrey Epstein,' including text messages, emails, and social media messages, showing a broad evidence-gathering scope.
The subpoena is signed by U.S. Attorney Geoffrey S. Berman, who was leading the Southern District of New York's prosecution of Epstein at the time.
The document references potential violations of federal statutes 18 U.S.C. §§ 371 (conspiracy), 1001 (false statements), and 1519 (destruction of evidence).
The recipient of the subpoena is not named in the provided text, indicating it is a redacted or separate attachment.
